content.raw:
It seems that Ubuntu and Windows are slightly different in how they demangle the symbol name of a class that was instantiated from a template.

The test assumes that spaces will be placed between the template arguments so that’s what I told the test to expect. But Windows \(which is what failed here\) does not put spaces between the template arguments within a symbol, so the lookup failed.

I made the test more robust here: b77d1f6 Now it will search for key components of the symbol name and choose the plugin name that contains those components instead of assuming a specific precise name.

Windows is happy now: [https://ci.appveyor.com/project/scpeters/ign-plugin/build/1.0.31](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/scpeters/ign-plugin/build/1.0.31)

\(I started a new Jenkins job for Windows, but the Jenkins server doesn’t seem to be responding.\)
content.html:
It seems that Ubuntu and Windows are slightly different in how they demangle the symbol name of a class that was instantiated from a template.

The test assumes that spaces will be placed between the template arguments so that’s what I told the test to expect. But Windows (which is what failed here) does not put spaces between the template arguments within a symbol, so the lookup failed.

I made the test more robust here: b77d1f6 Now it will search for key components of the symbol name and choose the plugin name that contains those components instead of assuming a specific precise name.

Windows is happy now: https://ci.appveyor.com/project/scpeters/ign-plugin/build/1.0.31

(I started a new Jenkins job for Windows, but the Jenkins server doesn’t seem to be responding.)
